Could it be that people are exercising their 2nd Amendment rights to buy guns and then flogging them on the black market to criminals?" Thats one of the dumbest arguments I've ever heard in regards to this subject. So because we have guns, it's our fault that criminals can obtain them in Paris or London. I though you guys had stopped crime since banning guns How in the world do criminals in countries which have such strict laws still manage to get guns and commit crimes??? Give me a break. America is not Europe. It was relatively easy to ban guns in Europe because there were so few there to begin with, not to mention the fact that Europeans have no right to own them and have much lower crime rates to begin with. You've actually touched on my point - a lot of criminals are getting guns from the US via the black market. Old Eastern European weapons are still common but the newer stuff that the police are confiscating is often apparently US in origin. Guns made and sold legally in Europe tend to be traceable but US sourced ones often drop off the radar once they've left the factory or importer. The plod who came 'round to inspect my gun cabinet last time I renewed my firearms certificate told me about a collection of pistols that had been seized in a raid - they were mostly German in origin (Walthers and H&Ks IIRC) but when they called the factorys in an attempt to track the suppliers they were told that they'd all been exported to the US within the last year and the last the companies knew of them was when they went to the dealers. Now I'm not suggesting that you should all have to have certificates and register your serial numbers with plod - that would be too sensible - but I don't think it's too much to ask for all gun dealers to have to keep records of who they sell to and for all gun owners to keep records of who they pass a gun on to. It's not a perfect system but it should at least make people think responsibly when they pass weapons on. Grachus - I know what you're on about and to my mind it shows up one of the glaring problems with immutable written constitutions. A perfectly sensible concept 200 years ago is rendered dubious by the progress of technology.
